raw_text: The first approach to predict user judgments on the basis of interaction metrics is the well-known PARADISE model (Walker et al, 1997)
clean_text: The first approach to predict user judgments on the basis of interaction metrics is the well-known PARADISE model (Walker et al, 1997).

raw_text: There are also well-known evaluation efforts such as EAGLES (Sparck Jones and Galliers, 1996) and the Paradise evaluation framework (Walker et al, 1997)
clean_text: There are also well-known evaluation efforts such as EAGLES (Sparck Jones and Galliers, 1996) and the Paradise evaluation framework (Walker et al, 1997).

raw_text: Walker et al (1997) identified three factors which carry an influence on the performance of SDSs, and which therefore are thought to contribute to its quality perceived by the user: agent factors (mainly related to the dialogue and the system itself), task factors (related to how the SDS captures the task it has been developed for) and environmental factors (e.g. factors related to the acoustic environment and the transmission channel)
clean_text: Walker et al (1997) identified three factors which carry an influence on the performance of SDSs, and which therefore are thought to contribute to its quality perceived by the user: agent factors (mainly related to the dialogue and the system itself), task factors (related to how the SDS captures the task it has been developed for) and environmental factors (e.g. factors related to the acoustic environment and the transmission channel).

raw_text: The PARADISE framework (Walker et al, 1997) produces such a relationship for a specific scenario, using multivariate linear regression
clean_text: The PARADISE framework (Walker et al, 1997) produces such a relationship for a specific scenario, using multivariate linear regression.

raw_text: As stated above, the separation of environmental, agent and task factors was motivated by Walker et al (1997)
clean_text: As stated above, the separation of environmental, agent and task factors was motivated by Walker et al (1997).

raw_text: In particular, unlike the PARADISE framework (Walker et al, 1997), which aims to evaluate dialogue agent strategies? by relating overall user satisfaction to various other metrics (task success, efficiency measures, and qualitative measures)? our approach takes the agent? s dialogue strategy for granted (in 279 utterance user typed response system (speech act) NLU user speech act DM Figure 1: Simplified pipeline architecture
clean_text: In particular, unlike the PARADISE framework (Walker et al, 1997), which aims to evaluate dialogue agent strategies by relating overall user satisfaction to various other metrics (task success, efficiency measures, and qualitative measures) our approach takes the agent's dialogue strategy for granted.
